Interior Door Maintenance:
Interior doors must periodically need adjustment. Temperature, humidity and normal house settlement will affect many aspects of a home, especially interior doors. Here are a few common adjustments that will be required from time to time and an some simple fixes you can make:
Problem - The door will not stay closed in the frame...
This may be due to some of the issues above. If the alignment of the door strike (latch) has moved or become misaligned, a quick and easy solution may be this:

1) Apply some lipstick on the protruding door lock (this is the part that moves when the handle is turned)

2) With the doorknob turned to the "open" position, close the door and release the knob

3) Open the door again and observe where the lipstick mark is in relation to the hole in the strike plate located on the door jamb

4) Take the door strike plate off (usually 2 screws) and re-position it so that the hole is in a position over all of the lipstick area you observed previously

(Note: you may have to remove a small amount of wood from the door jamb. To accomplish this be sure to use a small wood chisel for safety)

5) When finished, shut the door and gently pull without turning the knob. If the door stays put, you have successfully accomplished your mission!
Problem - The door will not stay in an "open" position, but slowly closes instead...
This is called a "sleeping door". Cute name, but very aggrevating to some people. Most place books in front of the door which become more of a nuisance, others purchase plastic wedges called "doorstops" to help with the problem. Fortunately, there is a very simple and effective method to repair this:

1) Use a small hammer and nail on the underside of the top hinge pin to tap the pin free

2) On a hard surface (try the concrete on a patio or sidewalk) lay the pin down and give it a firm hit in the center with a hammer. This should cause a slight bow in the pin, thereby increasing friction on the hinge when the pin is re-installed

3) Using the hammer, tap the pin back into the door hinge.

This usally always works with the first attempt. If not, repeat the same steps above with a different hinge pin until the door stops "sleeping".
Return to previous page
Problem - A door is warped and no longer fits in the frame correctly...
Unfortunately, this problem usually requires replacement. A qualified contractor should be sought for repairs. If you home is covered by a builders warranty program, check first to see if paint has been applied on "all" edges of the door including the top and bottom. This is usually always required by manufacturer warranties. If paint is missing in these areas it likely has warped due to improper installation. The builder should be contacted to evaluate this issue.
